Point 1: correct. Point 2: correct. Point 3: correct. Point 4: correct. Point 5: correct. Point 6: correct. Point 7: incorrect (it's not due to development, it's due to other parameters like deadlines) 

I'll add one point : Don't trust others blindly even microsoft... You dynamically add a control like a TreeView in your application and then you dynamically add datas into it but a lot of data and then you see that your application is unresponsive while data is being added and even slowed down... You check on Microsoft and see a lot of examples telling you how to add nodes and so on... But these samples are lie. They work with very small projects... Then you have to find yourself that deactivating the treeview, adding the data and then reactivating the treeview is the solution and nowhere on microsoft they will tell you that.

Another example : Add Windows Forms to your powershell project and run it. When it's processing something, you can't move the form on the screen, it's like blocked... Solution, make a tick loop with asynchronous jobs. You can then move your form while code is running.

Hi Friend.  I'd have a few items to add, but you hit it on the head.  I used to program more than I do now.  Now a days it's configuring linux file servers and Doing full everything on Streaming  Web servers using FSTAB, Javascript, PHP and so many libraries I cant count anymore.  I started with TRS-80 BASIC back in 1980.  I maxed out BASIC language, too slow.  I then taught myself the Zilog Z80 architecture, addressing modes and instruction set.  I graduated with computer programming honors in 1982.  I got an Atari box, so I had to learn the MOS 6502 chip.  Wow, the architecture was different on a 6502 than a Z-80.  I took me 6 months to really get the hang of Zero page addressing and how to make the 6502 really perform.  Now I deal with intel x86 and x64 code.  and Linux servers and Photoshop and web page development.   I build the boxes from scratch, configure the CLI Linux servers then I gotta put in SSL, streaming engines, I'm 61 now.  I still do it all as a hobby.  Resursive DNS Pi-Hole?  fucking OPNsense firewalls.  rooting phones..  I agree with everytihng you say, and more.  Love you!

Engineer with 15+ years of experience here. I agree with almost everything you said, bro â€” solid take.
But I just hope that the guy with 1.7M views didnâ€™t take the â€œperfection is a mythâ€ idea too literally.
Yes, perfection is impossible â€” but we should still aim for it. Not to the point of burnout or over-engineering, of course, but striving for clean, maintainable code is critical. Why? Because it forces you to look at solutions from different angles and often leads to better long-term outcomes.
More importantly: maintenance costs.
No one wants to join a company and be stuck fixing a 1,000-line stored procedure or deciphering a component where someone scattered boolean flags across multiple files â€” just to change a button color that shouldâ€™ve taken 5 minutes, but now takes 5 hours.
As devs, we wouldnâ€™t want to work on that mess. And we shouldnâ€™t leave it for others, either.
That â€œI wonâ€™t be here in 5 years, not my problemâ€ mindset? Itâ€™s toxic. The client may not care about code quality, but the company should â€” because in the end, theyâ€™re paying for human hours. And I doubt they want to spend hundreds of dollars on something that shouldâ€™ve been a 5-minute task.
So yeah â€” most of what you said is spot on, but Iâ€™d add this:
Always aim for clean, maintainable code. Maybe not perfection â€” but definitely professionalism.

Here's the 10 things:

*You donâ€™t need to know everything
* Learn how to learn (build, donâ€™t just watch)
* Perfection is a trap: ship it anyway
* Youâ€™ll never feel ready, start anyway
* The real skill is problem solving, not memorizing
* Nobody cares about code elegance, only results
* Burnout is real, protect your energy
* Value comes from working solutions, not vanity code
* Confidence comes from doing, not waiting
* Productivity is about sustainability, not grinding

I would say that "Nobody Cares About Your Code," is 40%-75% true. I've worked at firms where people are very nitpicky and where the caliber of coder was 10x at FAANG or/and Ivy League level. So yes, there companies and colleagues that just want it to work but there's a healthy percentage that are very nitpicky about all the small details and look at both sides of the coin.

"No one cares what your code looks like, they only cares if it's working." - that's a half truth. Yes, they may not care about the code per se, but care if you can adapt it to changing requirements without taking ages or messing things up (and I mean real pivots not button color changes). They may also care if they can bring someone else to help on short notice, because the timelines changed. That's when keeping the code clean and maintainable pays off. You will indeed hardly ever get paid for doing it, but doing it will help you stay in demand.

Here is one more advice. Don't think you can stick to one technology all the time.
On every project you will be required to do something that is out of your comfort zone. 
You wont be able to get away just saying: "sorry I am a FE dev, I dont do deployments...."
Truth is that most project are moving towards devops engineering where you will be required to do everything, including FE, BE, CI/CD, writing professional documentation,  discuss development strategies with client while also recommending solutions that can save them more money, handling clusters and production database, writing automated tests and much more.
And if you not fancy any of these you will definitely be in the next wave of roll offs

If it were as simple as you say, inserting a comma in the wrong place would be corrected by the compiler. But that's impossible because it requires a deeper understanding of the code's expectations.. The compiler won't guess what you meant it demands precision. And precision means taking into account many factors you don't even realize need to be built in to get real output data. The factors themselves must be of a specific size, and their duration is sometimes dependent on other factors. So, that's precision, and you need to be aware of this because one comma in the wrong place makes the entire precise process less precise.

Next time, think about what you're saying with this cooking analogy;/. There's no compiler where you insert basic function blocks, define the framework for their exchange of information and the expected results, and then the compiler modifies the code to meet those expectations. This is possible through AI, but sometimes it takes many weeks of repeating many blocks over and over again to find the desired solution. 

The concept of debugging, printf(), console.log(), is also poorly described even by advanced programmers. It's merely feedback to the terminal about whether a given line of code executed according to conditions. You talk about the importance of debugging, but you can't elaborate.

20+ years dev and 15+ QA here. Getting past QA is not an exam. It's a collaboration. QA knows your code won't be perfect. It's QAs job to define the tests and required test data to prove the code operates correctly within specified use cases. None of this should be a secret. You can ask for guidance. The smart devs would always ask me to create test data for them early to use in their unit tests. There would be some 'interesting' edge cases and failure cases in there, which the devs would 'fix' before it even went into QA. And when it did, it would sail through. Which saves me having to raise bugs and all that admin. ;-)

For those who are starting to work or study in this field I would also add two more tips:
1-always document and save your codes into a git repository, or cloud, or even on multiple hard drives. Doesn't matter if the code is stupid or looks stupid, it's the manifestation of your time and effort and if lost will never come back. Also, people would be surprised on how many times most coders rewrote the same functions and classes again and again. Save your time and save your effort.

2-get a decent template of a project in your language and use it for your codes. Most people start learning and don't care much about the project structure (just leave source codes, compiled files, documentation and build scripts on same place). It's importante to find or build a decent project structure and keep using it, because it's what professional coders do on the industry. 
When I was an undergraduate and also a graduate in C.S. I didn't have this structure. Then I joined some companies and learned how to keep my code organized and well structured. And let me tell you, it made all the difference. So if you are starting, ask some coder you know who was more experience for some direction on this project structure.

So that's it. I hope someone who's learning reads this and it helps them.

Great video and suggestions! I completely agree with all of them, except for the emphasis on code quality. If you encounter a client who doesn't prioritize code quality, then meet their needs but advise them that future changes or feature additions might feel like starting the project from scratch.

After 25 years of experience (I still think I do not know enough to apply for ...), I've only prioritized code structure in the last five years, thanks to Uncle Bob and others. This is why I don't entirely agree with avoiding perfectionism. I might spend a few days devising the most elegant solution, but once I have an idea, I can often implement it in about an hour, avoiding multiple failed attempts by thinking it through beforehand (which would take days). Work smart, not hard!

Naming is another crucial aspect; spending 10-15 minutes to name a function can save you hours when revisiting your code months later, especially in long-term projects.

However, I do agree that being able to write quick, rough code is essential for prototyping and testing ideas. Do this first to identify potential issues, then refactor. This leads to test-driven development, a skill worth mastering, but unless you have at least 10 years of experience, focus on developing other, more critical skills first.

I have 30 years of software development experience. Some of  what you say and the general flavour of it is good. But some of the detail isn't quite right. 
1) People do care about the code. Ask anyone who's failed a code review because the code didn't conform to standards, or didn't include unit tests. 
2) Every tutorial you do should have a purpose. It's not about how many hours you spend on it. It's about what purpose it serves. Doing tutorial after tutorial to learn syntax isn't helpful. Just do one or 2. Then yes apply the knowledge. But learning the right way first will save you a very long time developing bad habits you have to break and producing junk that will cause problems.
3) The best coders are the one who are driven to solve the problems and bend the computer to their will.
4) Here's a really tough one to swallow: Sometimes you will build excellent solutions and they will be rejected for bureaucratic reasons. I've had excellent work thrown out for the most illogical reasons during my career. If this is happening often, you might want to consider what other opportunities are out there.

I'm self-taught, but different from what you said in the video. I knew I had to figure out how to learn and gain experience, rather than just watching content about it. I started my "journey" January 2017, after dropping out of school. Did study ICT, but lost motivation, as all I learned during the first 5 months was the Norwegian words used in the field (yes, I'm Norwegian) and other things wasn't great back then. My journey started as a userscript coder for a text based web game, after I developed both a very simple website with PHP and MySQL and a Discord bot using NodeJS for a clan on Clash Royale, the mobile game.

Fun fact, about a year after starting coding, I realized that I really knew little, when I then realized that NodeJS was what I developed the Discord bot in. Shortly after, I started playing a lot with NodeJS, and fell in love with it. Sure, JS isn't perfect, and debugging it can be pain, sometimes, but there was a time I literally felt more confident in JS, than my native language, Norwegian.

The last few years, I haven't really been coding a lot, but I've personally been focused more on hardware knowledge, networking, security, automation, and so on, and while I've been more focused on those things, I've rather kept my programming brain updated by helping a friend through his bachelor degree. By that, I've learned stuff about Java too. Not a lot, as I've been learning about multiple languages during the time since I begun learning programming.

My experience has led me to believe that perfection is unattainable and should not be strived for in a majority of cases. I was in a fast paced industry (film/animation) before where features that where requested in the pipeline would ultimately take weeks or months to implement properly, and there were several instances where the production  has already shipped and yet the feature is still in discussion. It's better to get something in front of the artists in a state that gives them close to what they want with an added apology. It opens up the conversation and builds trust too. Perfect code doesn't matter to much for most cases because like you said "nobody cares of your code".

In anyoneâ€™s career there are three things: money, respect, and impact.  People, your boss or users, only care about impact.  Your workmates, if you have any, more so care about your code.  Thatâ€™s the respect part, partially.  You care about the money, but really all three.  And when I talk about money I mean more or less the right amount, not too little and not too much also.  If you get all three of those right, that is a successful career.  You will get some of those right and not others or in varying degrees.

Been a developer for over a year, and my current workplace has caused me to burn out to the point where I don't care if things go downhill or I get fired. While it felt nice that there are people who think similarly (at least 3 of these points were clear to me already), it's just not helping.

It makes me want to step away from coding for a few months, just going out there to touch grass etc, then finding another dev job.

The biggest reason for my burnout is that we have project managers and product owners, yet most of managing the project is left to us devs, and the project managers rarely reflect or try to improve things.

Things get built when the design isn't even signed off yet, then they stare at us devs like lost chicken when the client doesn't sign it and wants changes.
Things that were underplayed and agreed to before seeking a dev's opinion bite us in the ass and cause overtime and unnecessary stress.
No real project documentation. No feature documentation. All of it is purely in the form git, tickets/issues + comments.
No documentation for feature agreements with the client. Just a call and maybe a quick email sign-off, then that gets lost cos it was handled by someone who left the company.
It's also boring cos it's basically a platform and 99% of things are already built, just rethemed or shuffled around a bit or extended/improved slightly.

Made me wonder, is it me, or is it the company? Idk anymore, but I'm sick of it.

2:50 perfection might be a lie, but clean code is not, most people today still do not write clean code, what do i mean by that, is to decide a standard and stick with it in the context of tabs parentheses brackets how to write variables, when to use camelCase, PascalCase, or snake_case, i had issues writing postgres queries on code because postgres does not likes camelCase and some of the variable were written in such way, it creates more work while you are trying to develop, also variable names, try to keep consistent, it makes code easier to read, track, fix, write, etc, you pretty much do not have to think about those things because there is already a set agreement, sure people can be opinionated sometimes, but in any project i touch, i try to adhere to the preset of the project, there is a reason why the original coder wrote it that way, unless you realize it was really bad code, but i have work with old code and it not almost hard to follow, it almost looks spaghetti, although some algorithms were clever and some abstraction was reusable, a lot of times it was very inconsistent to the point that even with a MVC framework some view was on the controller and not the view, other logic was ion the model not the controller, etc...and with today's pretty tools it should not be an excuse for beginners, a lot of people might not like to use prettier tools, but i strongly suggest for beginners until you find your own way

I taught myself assembler when I was 14 - this was pre-internet days - using DOS's debug.exe.  Later I discovered MASM, but at first I wrote small programs entirely in Debug, learning assembler through trial and error.  I had some help from the library, but it was 80% experimentation.  Learning high level languages after that was easy.  For me, learning any new language is just picking up the syntax to express the same underlying archetypes that we all use..  They come in many names, but a common name for those archetypes are "programming patterns".  As Jung said, language is only a vehicle for communicating archetypes. The archetypes matter â€” not the words themselves.  Programming languages are very similar.  In short, don't make it harder than it really is.
Real developers don't write java script

I helped develop computer software/games starting in 1994. I can tell you every game I ever worked on including he last. I will talk at length about the last game as it was for Netdevil for Lego and was Called Lego Universe. That game put me out of developing forever. Code is loads of typing then copy pasting as much as possible for as little cost as possible with no internal testing ever. 

 What I learned was studios were set up to fail at every step because bankrupting a studio is a write off. The teams I worked with on Dark Ages of Camelot were not the same team in 2 years. Anyone that did anything right was gone before it was a success. 

 Studios are a letter head to be closed down for profits if successful and blame if not, but still a tax write off. 

 All of my developing and coding days were done in the states and the minute I left in 2012 to work on Indy titles posted for sell on Steam, my life changed. I was being paid for my work based on my work and I started to learn from mistakes instead of fearing my contract would be up in 2 years.

 Do not work for triple A studios if you care about what you are doing, work for them if you are a throw away staff member no one cares about unless it pushes an agenda.

 edit: I wasted soo much time from 2006-2012 trying to make polished graphics and spent little to know time on execution because the studios I worked under did not care about content or replay, they all wanted minimal content that looked good in trailers and nothing more. 

 So if you are not good enough or confident enough to create your own project and you must work under the thumb of a big studio, know from the day you start , you are on the chopping block and nothing you think you are there for, will ever matter. You will simply reskin everything, copy paste quest, copy paste items and areas. Those of you that may want to know if I worked on larger MMOs than Dark ages of Camelot, the answer is yes and it was the worst experience of my life and I will never return to California based only on working with those reject drones. Thankfully for them microtransactions have kept that game alive 15 years longer than it deserves.
_"Perfection is the enemy of good enough."_

Your teammates care about your code. To save time in communication, maintenance, merging, and iteration, conform to your team's standards & best practices. Don't bring your style/practices from your past job or experience. Auto-format on commit helps a lot here. And hopefully, your team follows the standards & conventions in the documentation of your language & framework.

something i wanted to add as a student (computer engineering) that i think might help other students:

try to love writing code. maybe you got into this because it seemed like relatively easy money, or maybe you got into it for some other reason, but if you don't love code, it's hard to keep doing it.

also try to write code in your down time, like during breaks when classes aren't in session. my peers who didn't touch C++ at all for 3 months struggled a little when we returned. i was happy to help them out, but unfortunately not everyone has friends they can depend on, and not everyone has friends in their field of study.

at the end of the day, if you like it enough that you can do it for money without sacrificing your physical and mental health, you should go after it regardless. write code

"Nobody cares about your code". Hard disagree. The most important person in the world does: me. He's also the person who I'll be f* over if I don't write clean, elegant and maintainable code, since he's the poor schmuck who'll have to extend and maintain it. Writing clean and elegant code is not just a vanity thing; it's what ensures the product you're building can survive years in production while evolving to changing user requirements. Perhaps you just write one-off web apps that need to run for a couple of months, and then they're retired, or perhaps you just do the initial delivery and it's someone else's problem after you're gone, but that's a real crappy attitude to bring to work.

I share a similar experience, but I have a different take on the idea that "Nobody cares about your code." In a team setting, clean code with an intelligent and modular structure is important because it makes it much easier for other, often younger, developers to read and understand. This saves them time that can be used for other work. Customers often request changes that can cause problems, and with good code, you can confidently say, "I need X days for that change." This allows you to finish the work ahead of schedule, use the extra time to complete other tasks that are behind, and ultimately get paid for the work you did. Of course, it's all about finding the right balance and maintaining good ethics!

I've been a "coder" since the 80s.  Yeah, I was like 7 or 8 when dad got the first Commodore machine, but I fell in love with the 64 and still own that very exact machine and monitor and the three 1541 disk drives my dad bought new.  I learned the hard knocks very well on that machine and even today as a proper systems administrator for a world wide company.

#1> Foundational information is absolutely necessary.  Forget the language, remember the process.  I Google (Now ChatGPT) how to do some basic stuff
#2> I'm currently learning and documenting some Ansible playbooks.  I'm writing a set of documents on the modules I'd  be using regularly to reference.
#3> When you start at a programming language with a limited length of variable name (Two characters!) your choices are limited.  I still use "for x:=0 to 10" today.  Refactoring code is a later process.
#4> With how software changes, I found you're never going to know everything.  You can only dig into what's on the field right now, because next week, it's probably going to change.  EXPECT to have things changed.
#5> Modularization, small chunks, small functions/procedure, very specific tasks in code... This makes this so much easier to figure out if you throw intentional bad data at your SMALL routines.  Tracing, line by line.
#6> I kind of agree with this, but the programmer looking at your code in three months, you need some decent style in the code.  To START, yeah, the code will look horrible, but with refinement, you'll be able to get it so that you could be a couple years out and look at the code and figure out what it's supposed to do either just LOOKING at the code or reading the documentation and have faith your younger self knew what they were doing. ;)
#7> Burnout IS real.  Not only for coding, but for EVERYTHING you regularly do over and over again.  Distraction is necessary, diversion is necessary, stepping back for a little while is necessary.  If a part of the code doesn't work, remove it, stub it, know it's broken and move onto something else.  Your brains background processor will think on the problem and get you straight again eventually.  Even at 4am.  Been there too.  No cold sweat wake-up, but certainly have woken up with an AH-HA thought and went back to sleep.

"Seasoned" developer here (20+), and the only point I'd like to add to is your "nobody cares about your code".  While I totally get the point you're making, its not entirely true.  Anyone who has to support the code behind you will 'care.  Tech debt is real, and sloppy code that just works, over time, tends to create more hassles than the time they save just pushing "working" code out the window.  I totally agree, the client doesn't care how the sausage is made, but the other cooks will care if the recipe's a mess and takes too much of their time to modify or update.   Again this is NOT to detract from your point to the viewers (don't worry so much about your code you don't do it or release it, ultimately no one will care about it), I just don't want to lose sight of the folks that actually will (even if your a distant memory ğŸ˜Š).

And for anyone who is more interested in systems administration, providing a cloud or similar: It's almost the same. 

So whenever I meet an apprentice or someone who just entered the business, the first thing I tell them: Your most important ability is to get along with waiting even if customers are pushing you to get things done fast. e.g. You will have to wait for installations to finish, systems will reboot slowly before you can continue and don't you do something else because when you start multi-tasking you will make mistakes. So: Don't even try to be fast, don't even try to be perfect, make sure that the tasks you do actually result in a system state that does what it is supposed to do. Then if you mastered the ability to wait without doing some other task, you need to learn to do this when the customer is pushing you to get things done fast. Rule of thumb: There are no fast solutions. There are only things that work and those that don't and the time it takes to get them done is the time they will have taken. More often then not a problem is simply solved by doing nothing for ten minutes. And the solutions that work and are done fast often are the ones that will result in problems that you just don't see when you implement them. So stick to solving the problem or implementing just the next feature before turning towards the one after that and take the time that is necessary so that it is done properly. And if you mastered this you get to the hardest part: Nobody will recognized that you did a proper job because they do not understand what the actual job is. In systems anything that anyone will see is when things do not work as the user expects them to. So nobody will see that you did a great job. Because doing a great job means that the systems will run as the user expects. And even when users have caused a problem, they will point the finger at the system or even at you. But if you do a decent job you'll have a decent income and more than enough time to make projects you'd like to invest time and noone will care about how many hours you actually have to invest to get your job done.
Coders will all be serving lattes at Starbucks in the end. Ai will take all the coding jobs.

Learning to Code Effectively
ğŸ”„
Transitioning from consuming tutorials to creating your own projects is essential for real learning.
 
â°
A productive rule is to spend four times as much time building as you do watching tutorials.
 
ğŸ—
Building real projectsâ€”even imperfect onesâ€”enhances skills far more than passive consumption.
Embracing Imperfection in Development
ğŸ”¥

ğŸ‘·â€â™‚

âœ”

Problem-Solving as a Core Skill

Managing Burnout and Maintaining Balance

I followed tutorials when I did my first few projects, but during school we were taught one thing one at a time, and then told to make something from what we learnt

My first program was like. Nestled if else nightmare cus it was the only thing we learnt, but while doing so I realized the limitations, and as I play tested I kept finding more stuff I wanted to fix

Then next time we learnt for and while loops, which I immediately found a way to use to solve a lot of the if else issues.

Then we learnt about methods, etc. Etc. And I just kinda built from that.

Every time I learnt something new. I used it. I played with it. I spent time understanding what it did and stretching it to it's limits.

When I learnt something new, I looked to see if I could use it to fix issues I had before. Then I did it again. And again.

I'm not a good coder, but I understand my code well, and I know what every single thing I write down is supposed to do, and if I don't, I study it.

People don't always have time for this, but it's insanely helpful.

I was doing my first game jam a month ago, and I followed a tutorial for a character creator.

I hadn't coded anything for a year, so I forgot how to even do anything in unity. How do I make code... Connect to the objects? That's how much I forgot.

But the moment I finished the tutorial I started doing my own thing, and it was working! It was working really well, and when it broke, I could accurately guess why.

When I couldn't find tutorials for what I needed? I followed one that was similar, learnt something new that I could use in other places, but also I could discern what I needed for my plan to work, and what I didn't really need.

I only write and/or delete lines when I know what it does, that way I don't explode everything lmao

We all have stupid issues too of, programming does that to you. If you haven't had a silly mistake during programming that cost you what felt like 50 years off your life, have you ever done programming?

I once got stuck for a month due to forgetting to reset the velocity on my character, which was a really silly mistake, but it happens!

Good tip: all the bugs come out when you try recording your progress. Even after testing out everything before and it working fine, the moment you try showing it to others it starts falling apart, trust. Good way to find new bugs fr

On a serious note, what I like to do when testing out where a bug is happening (usually if I suspect a variable is at fault or if I can't locate the exact location) use debug.log/console.writeline/your equiv!

It helps a lot because not only can you make the program tell you what the values of the variables are (if you suspect there's an issue with one, especially if a lot of variables are used in one line so you can't tell which one... Me doing undo redo function with 12 variables to save... I hate you undo redo...)
But if you can't locate the issue, you can put down some "marks" to see which one fires off before things explode. If one doesn't fire before the game breaks, then the issue must be happening between the last that worked and the one that didn't.

Helps on places where it breaks later in the code but you can't tell because the computer processes it so quickly so it feels like it breaks 100 lines earlier. Happened to me before. Crashes a whole 150 lines before the actual issue, spent 30 minutes looking there only to realize it came later.

Anyway, I'm not very experienced, I programmed like. Four things. One was my 12 nestled if else statements hell (yes. I counted there was 12. It was horrifying truly), two was my second attempt using for and while loops so the program loops until you answer something valid, third was programming the game "Meyer" using the console, I used a lot of methods for that one, and the AI was really good at the game too :3, fourth was my finals project where I programmed a pomodoro timer with a cat, where if you touched it while you're supposed to be studying it would hiss at you and lower affection, but on break time you could pet it for some affection, but it didn't demand your time so you could do other things on break.

And then my game jam game like. A month ago :3 which was pretty big compared to my other stuff. It was "just a dress up" but istg undo redo? Hatred. More stuff was annoying but those two are my mortal enemy.

But it helped!! You don't even have to learn one thing at a time like they do in school. That was just an example of how I started out, but if you learn a new thing in a tutorial, think about where else you could use it!

I learnt grids for a pop up menu that would show all the available options, but then I realized. Hey. I could use these to make my life easier someplace else.

Its pretty self explanatory, but maybe someone will find it helpful. Don't just copy paste, look at what the code does, and see if you could use it somewhere else.

When I learnt for and while loops I didn't use it how they taught us in the example. I used it for dialogue! Until you gave a valid response, it would loop the question.

Is there a better way to do it? Maybe. Was it better than what I had previously? Absolutely.

And that's what matters. Is the code better than before? Yes? Good! You're improving!
And hey you found a cool way to use it, that's epic! Next time you learn something, maybe you can improve it even more!

You don't need a big project to "start writing" you can start with something super tiny and simple. You can start following a tutorial and building on that. It can be the smallest ever game, but its something you made. It exists. It runs. If it doesn't? Fix it! Now you learnt what went wrong!

Debugging. Creation. Optimisation. Injection. Disection. Each have their own fields. But also there are skills that grow beyond. Stitching. Compatibility. Expandability.

Itâ€™s because of your sixth rule that thereâ€™s so much lousy code on github.
Itâ€™s because of your sixth rule that project has to be rewritten â€” work that doesnâ€™t take code quality into account.
The sixth rule is the rule of quick payment and quick loss of your client.

If, a year after writing code in the spirit of the sixth rule, youâ€™re asked to modify it, you wonâ€™t even know where to begin.

If you do meticulous work and your code is of high quality, that should matter to you personally.
And indeed, youâ€™re right that no one looks at the quality of your code.
But even so, the code still has to be clean, understandable, reusable, maintainable, and usable by others.

What should really be shared with beginner programmers is that the fundamental key to carrying out a good project is planning, thinking ahead, outlining the problems, and searching for solutions â€” all before writing a single line of code.

They need to immerse themselves in the project they want to build, but first they must understand it, gain a clear overview, and then plan. Only after that, once a proper plan is in place, should coding begin â€” and an essential part of coding is testing.

This is how you can create code that is completed quickly, because it isnâ€™t full of unnecessary dead ends; code that is reusable and can be extended at any time, because the tests will show when a new development has had a negative impact on an earlier feature.

These are the things that should be talked about.

About the plumbing.. You actually want a plumber who works cleanly, at least I assume. Whenever there is an issue that needs to be fixed.. you don't want that to get messy xD. Same for coding, if your structure is shit, it will be hard to make changes. But you shouldn't focus on perfection that much in the beginning.

You don't need to know everything. Real developers don't memorize every detail; they know how to find answers and use patterns.

It's okay to Google basic things oftenâ€”itâ€™s part of being a good developer and learning how to learn.

Learning coding is like learning a language: watching tutorials isnâ€™t enough; you have to actually write code to become fluent.

Spend at least four times as much building and coding on your own as you do consuming tutorials to truly learn.

Perfection is a trap. Do not obsess over writing perfect or elegant code before you ship.

Done is better than perfect. Shipping code that works teaches more than perfect code that never finishes.

You will never feel ready. Start anywayâ€”even if scared or uncertain, action builds confidence and opens doors.

The real skill is problem solving, not just writing code. Learn to break down problems and debug effectively.

Nobody cares about how clever your code isâ€”they care about what it does and if it solves the problem.

Burnout is real. Protect your energy by taking breaks, setting boundaries, and caring for your mental health.

Additional expanded practical insights based on these:

Donâ€™t feel bad if you need to look things up constantlyâ€”even advanced devs do it regularly.

Shift your mindset from passive learning to active creating as early and often as possible.

Get comfortable with making mistakes and breaking things; this is where real learning happens.

Avoid overthinking variable names or tiny details early on; focus on functionality first.

Code reviews and feedback help improve code over timeâ€”embrace iterative improvement.

Confidence builds from doing real projects, freelancing, or contributing to open sourceâ€”even if imperfect.

Debugging is a core part of development; see bugs as puzzles, not failures.

Prioritize writing code that solves the userâ€™s needs above â€œcleanlinessâ€ or â€œbest practicesâ€ at first.

Set sustainable work habitsâ€”coding productivity is about pace you can maintain long term.

Celebrate progress, no matter how small; every step forward matters in the learning journey.
Thank you

My biggest lesson in IT is that people need to communicate. Stop trying to solve everything on your own and ask for help from colleagues when you find yourself stuck.
Especially when I moved on to a more leadership role I observed how people were working on islands. Don't work on your island, build a supportive community. Have a question? Ask it. Stop spending 3 hours going through documentation. Someone on Teams knows the answer and can tell you it in 5 seconds.

Communication is actually the reason I became a team lead. My programming is not as good as some of my team members, but at least I can talk to business and organise the group. But now I am in charge of a team cause I am simply better at communicating.

1. *You don't need to know everything* - Real developers don't have every function memorized. It's about patterns, problem-solving, and finding answers (Googling is normal).

2. *Learn how to learn* - Watching tutorials isn't enoughâ€”you learn by building. Rule of thumb: for every 1 hour watching, spend 4 hours coding.

3. *Perfection is a trap* - No code is flawless; even senior devs break things. Shipping "ugly but working" code teaches more than chasing perfection.

4. *You'll never feel readyâ€”start anyway.* Confidence comes from doing, not waiting. Say yes, even if you feel scared or unprepared.

5. *The real skill is problem-solving.* Coding is less about syntax, more about breaking problems into chunks. Debugging isn't failureâ€”it's the job.

6. *Nobody cares about your code; they care about results.* Clients/users care about outcomes, not elegant code. Value > vanity.

7. *Burnout is realâ€”protect your energy.* Grinding nonstop doesn't make you better. Sustainability matters: take breaks, sleep, recharge.
How about coding best practices?

10 years developer here as well. All tips are accurate, apart from the "nobody cares about your code".
Most CEOs and other non-technical employees aren't knowledgeable enough about software engineering to know what "intrinsic quality" is. Ok, the final user doesn't care, and they shouldn't. But the person who is paying you so you handle them the complete and working SYSTEM (instead of offering them a SaaS), should definitely care about code quality. If they did know that code quality means a software that is robust and easy to extend and maintain - which translates directly in their words to "reduced costs" - then I assure you they would in fact care about your code.

Following your analogy, if I hire a plumber and instead of screwing a pipe to one another they connect one pipe to another using epoxy resin, then I would be mad as hell!
I (or the next plumber) would have to break everything to give maintenance again later on, even if it was just one pipe that was problematic.

I hope this video reaches the newer developers as well, they will greatly benefit from these tips!
Thanks man. All tips are true and real â¤

"Nobody cares about your code" - this is kind of attitude that JavaScript developers have and reason why JavaScript ecosystem is a shithole. The fact that your client doesn't care about your code is not an excuse to write shitty mess. You should care about your code, and if your boss doesn't then it's a shitty boss and you work in wrong place altogether. Sure that "perfection is a trap" and "you'll never feel ready", these are true. You will never reach perfection but you must try to, otherwise you will get yourself into trouble if that project you don't care about will be longer than one month.

That advice on burnout is curcial. It gave me gray hairs in my 20ties, a dark time with bad thoughts, switching jobs,  moving country and 3000 Euros worth of therapy to learn to have boundaries and not freak out. I still am dealing with the consequences of that time in my life and prolly will forever. Now I am paid for x amount of hours in a week. If I should work more, I need to be paid more. Sounds anti-grind minded, but I'd rather keep my mental health intact then to burn out on something that will not get me much further either. It's hard, because a lot of development is the constant flip between "I am a genius god!" to "Why did I ever touch a keyboard, and how am I even able to get dressed in the morning?" But keep your sanity, it is not worth it to ruin yourself for the rest of your life just for a random dude giving you a pat on the back and a free pizza on friday.

I watched this video and agreed with a lot of what was said, especially the idea that we donâ€™t need to know *everything*. But I think thereâ€™s something that shouldâ€™ve been clarified.

Yes, we donâ€™t need to know "everything" , but that doesnâ€™t mean we should settle for surface-level understanding. I personally want to learn everything "useful"â€” not to brag about it, but to actually fill the gaps and build a solid foundation. Iâ€™ve learned this the hard way: skipping things too quickly creates gaps that slow you down later.

So what I want to say is â€” you shouldâ€™ve pronounced it this way:  
â€œDonâ€™t try to learn everything at once.â€
Not:  
â€œYou donâ€™t have to know everything.â€

Thereâ€™s a big difference. One is about pace, the other sounds like permission to skip. And for some of us, skipping is not an option â€” weâ€™re in it for mastery.

I'm the only dev in my office without a degree
Company is paying for my BS in CS
how did I get here?
my personal rules: 
1. Get rid of all social media
2. Math is hard...Khan academy
3. Time management becomes a genuine skill. 
Apple watch allows for daily reminders (reminders on phone causes you to reach for your phone too much)
Start every day with a written list (created the day before) (yes written)
4. Manage your hours: I bought a "Gym boss" timer, set it to 15 minutes.
This keeps me focused on the task at hand. seems excentric.... but it works.
5. Drink water all day and get 10K steps daily  (have a walking pad to achieve this)

Final fact: Too many students nowadays are overusing Ai to complete thier assignments vice learning to code.
This narritive that coders are going to be fully replaced is false. Ai is nothing but a tool to be leveraged.
So, learn to leverage it. Ai will have its impact... but it won't replace us.

How about some more
+ code is disposable, just because you invested in it doesn't mean you should keep it! 
+ if you make an assumption about a feature, prove it. The customer rarely knows exactly what they want so don't just take their (or your) word for it. The earlier you prove it the better. Sometimes its much quicker and easier to do this on paper than in code
+ developers work better in a team, you challenge and learn from each other as you work. The code you produce is always better. Conversely one developer working solo is dangerous - if there is no-one to challenge you, how do you know you're doing it wrong?
+ good tests are worth the time it takes to write them and write the test first. That way you can prove your code works and that you only write testable code
+ there is no such thing as a rock star programmer
'The best developers I know the ones who last, they take breaks, they have boundaries.' Took me later to learn about self-preservation, esp at work. It's a marathon, not a sprint.

As Solution Architect with 27 years in the industry (don't ask me how I landed in this video - youtube magic :) ) - I fulhertedly confirm what this guy tells.
Impostor syndrom is strong - every year I just feel like - or there are still so much more to learn - I know nothing. Even though I'm miles ahead of most of my colleagues - sometimes some panic still fights me. Especially nowadays when technologies and frameworks are appearing and become out of date faster than you become expert with them. The good old days of "becoming really good in 1-2-3 key languages / libs / approaches" are long gone. It's a continuous race.
And yeah - I still google. And youtube, and learn. And read docs. Talk to colleagues. And still trying to catch up. Non stop. IT is the industry where you're never perfect to the job. You think - yeah, now I've seen it all - next project I'm coming ready ... and you still getting something you've never seen before. And trust me... I've seen quite a lot.

Huge caveat to #6 is you are writing that nice code for the next dev. Focus on making it work, but it is still important to think about the maintainability. How easy can I add a feature to this or change the way that it works. You can't just be the person who gets it done as fast as possible leaving an absolute nightmare in your wake. Find the balance.

That quality component can really hurt later devs down the road. I suppose the dev implementing later doesn't matter as the two likely never meet.  I have had to deal with some very sloppy implementations written by weekend warrior coders.  I learned some of the red flags as very novice coders typically say/do similar things.  If you ask about organization, they'll tell you to just read the code and understand it (No planned organization).  I recall opening up A SQL report and immediately recognizing unsafe grouping which meant the results were not deterministic.   Other red flags are no use of custom functions or classes, all variables are global, and magic numbers everywhere.  I have seen these problems at small companies to large international companies.

Been a software engineer for 20 years now, and the single greatest skill I ever developed was done very early in my journey. And that skill is the ability to step through my code, or anyone else's code, manually. Look at the inputs to a function, write them down, and assign values to them. Then walk through line by line and write down how those variables change until you reach the end. Verify that it's doing what you think it's doing. Repeat with different types and values for the inputs and ensure proper output is coming out the other side. I was super slow at this in the beginning, but it really helped me understand code at a more intimate level. I got so fast at this that I do it lie second nature, and I spend so much less time debugging and more time writing code that works. Highly recommend to everyone to get better at walking through code, not just with "happy path" variables (what you think they should be), but throw in weird ones to. If a variable is supposed to be an integer, what happens if a null gets passed in? Or an empty object? It really helps you add in safe-guards to your code to prevent bugs.
Great advice and not just in coding either, kudos good sir!

I agree with your first point, it's impossible to memorize everything, which is why AI tools have become such a blessing for developers. Instead of wasting time Googling or digging through stackoverflow threads, we can get straight to the point.

Yet, some developers are still against using AI tools for coding. They prefer the traditional ways of searching for solutions manually, or in some cases, it seems to come down to ego. They argue that AI generates bad code but the truth is, you can always review and tweak the output. Itâ€™s a starting point, not a final product.

Burnout is real. Iâ€™ve been there. Whatâ€™s scary is that many people donâ€™t even realize theyâ€™re going through it. That happened to me last year I constantly felt sleepy, unmotivated, and didnâ€™t want to work. After looking it up, I realized those were symptoms of burnout. The endless client requests and constant changes wore me down, and I started to hate coding.

But when I started using AI to help with coding, it made a huge difference. It saved me hours, even days, by providing boilerplate code or templates I could build on. AI isnâ€™t perfect, but it makes solving problems much faster and takes some of the pressure off.

A couple of things:

0:22 "You don't need to know everything" Technically correct but you really do want to learn as much as possible about a language. Your senior coworkers will not treat you well if your a junior not constantly learning more about the language. The less questions you need to ask, the happier they will be. It sucks but you can't avoid it. Seniors do no realize how much they know or how long it takes to get there when dealing with a Junior. Protect your career by learning what you can before you start the job and keep learning a bit almost every day so you already know what something does more of the time when you're reading code others wrote. The less help you need, the more likely you are to keep a job. It doesn't matter how fair it is, it's how most people will treat you.

I've been coding for 40 years now and these tips are great for beginners.
I've also been teaching coding for about 30 years (on and off) and most of these tips are some of the first I pass on.
My youngest son, for example, is into coding. He's 11 and I'm pretty sure we've gone over all those points. He was also worried that his code wouldn't be very good (moving from scratch to javascript), but thats the secret... we all started somewhere.
New coders need to realise that it takes time, but you will eventually get to the same point as us. It just takes practise. And even now, I'll look back on code thats only 2 or 3 years old, and my brain will go "what was I thinking?" XD
My javascript from 5 years ago, for example, looks little like my code today. And Im sure in 5 years time, it'll look totally different again.
The only other thing you need to be a good coder is that childlike curiosity to figure out how things work at a fundamental level. It will bring you joy when you find a solution.

What I learned in 20 years of experience:
 * Don't waste your time with webtech, it's bloated, it's complicated. And the solutions are often broken in many parts. It's impossible to actually understand how a browser works for a beginner. Too many solutions are just flailing around and sticking with whatever kind of works.
 * OOP rarely helps to solve a problem. Don't force OOP to anything. Non OOP solutions are often easier to maintain and faster to execute
 * Stop looking for libraries to solve every tiny detail of your software. If you think of solving it yourself, your are getting better, and you actually understand the solution you use and can adapt it, if necessary.
 * Stay away from frameworks. Frameworks don't compose. You can give up your main loop only once, and that's even too much. Frameworks prevent you from actually understanding what is going on in your software, and if something is wrong with them, the only path forward is getting the lube ready an bend over (figuratively).
 * Memory layouting and CPU caching is actually very very important. Could cause a 100x performance difference. Don't lock yourself into languages, where you have no control over that. Learn at least one of these languages for that: C, C++, Rust, Zig, Odin, Nim, Go (there are probably more that I can't name right now, but certainly not anything with Java* in its name)
 * Don't fix issues in your coworkers code, before communicating and them understanding and agreeing, that there is a problem. And then ask if you may fix it. Coworking can get really sensitive if you touch their precious.

5:47 - "Perfect code" whatever that means is not - in itself - a goal.

I hate it when people say that code quality doesn't matter or no one cares about your code. It's not about whatever arbitrary perfection you're chasing - it's about: can you evolve and maintain the code quickly and effectively to adapt to future business needs and growth without introducing bugs or performance issues. All the classic "rules" are just tools to achieve this in different contexts. The end goal of good and clean code is that you can keep moving fast and delivering quality in the other things you noted customers and bosses care about.

One example consequence of viewing it this way - if you're writing a one off tool that you and the people you're building it for see very little chance will ever be extended - go ahead and lower your standards significantly if that helps get it out fast. If you find out you were wrong and it does start evolving and let's say does so 3 times - then consider what tools would be useful to start using - maybe only in new code or maybe you rewrite it while it's small. If the former - if you're still extending it long after 3 times then you could choose to invest in going back and fixing whatever the original part was.

The above is just one example scenario - but notice how it's directly connected to the actual business problem and needs being solved for, instead of sitting in an abstract "I was taught this tool and therefore must use it" default mode.

I'll end by saying that dear god I ----ing hate working with people who don't care at all about the meaning of names, consistency, structure, etc. Those are all tools to make it easier to load all the context you need - and only what you need - back into your head when you come to the code again such that you can know what to do, do it, and do so without breaking things quickly. Ideally (and again this would apply for something that is likely or proven to need extension/maintenance) it would also enable people just coming to the tool to ramp up much faster - or maybe just even enable it in the first place by making it so they don't have to read your ----ing mind and see all the context and assumptions you didn't make explicit in the code (which then lead to endless bug and churn hell as they trip over them constantly if it's something non-trivial).

This is particularly bad given that if I need to read every line of code in a project to know what the hell is going on in one area such that I can modify it with confidence that I'm not introducing edge cases/race conditions/etc - it takes more cognitive energy from me than I have and I descend into a long bitter voyage to hell as the rest of my life withers and I start debating whether being alive is worth it (software engineering is my only monetization skill currently unfortunately - and working in environments like I'm describing makes it damn near impossible to make any real progress on learning anything else).

Good code - first off isn't about arbitrarily applying every "good code" tool you've learnt everywhere - and is for YOU and YOUR FELLOW AND FUTURE DEVELOPERS.

Completely dismissing/disregarding it (which I've had to work with before) is infuriating, arrogant, and short sighted - unless you're working on one of those things that never gets touched again (and how often does that assumption turn out wrong - so even with that why not at least name and structure things well and as close to what you're documenting as possible and use comments to note things you're ignoring, assumptions you're making, and so on (or better yet asserts).
Your coworkers will care about your code, if they have to fix something in it, or change it in any other way.

Nowadays even ChatGPT can help a lot and save a lot of time writing codes ready for you, but of course it will not complete the whole work always, need to know the code structures and basics yourself.

Certainly good advice. I suppose I am an odd ball in that I intuitively understood your advice as a very curious kid looking to understand the world around me back in the 60's and 70's. While I went into electrical engineering because computer science was not on my radar back then, your advice is really applicable to any problem solving field. There is simply too much to know, but learning to ask the right questions will get you what you need to know. 

I have always been a great problem solver and the one thing I notice that I have that many others don't have is the ability to not run out of options to try and questions to ask. I remember a project where another engineer and electrician where attempting to figure out why 5 computers around our plant would not communicate in a network. They spent a year intermittently working on the solution. The project was turned over to me and the instructions for communications was only about a page long. The problem is the writer wrote a problematic paragraph that in my mind could be interpreted in a multitude of ways. I spent the next few days applying the different ways the paragraph could be interpreted until I had success.

Pro tip: Just as hes said you don't need to know everything out of your head, however, there is something important that needs to be said because some people don't realize it and I am going to provide you an example.

Suppose there is a package that everyone wants to use and ask for it in their job posts, I won't mention any by name... *cough* Redux *cough*. Think you memorized exactly how to use it and implement it and write every declaration, and do it by memory perfectly, what happens is that if you don't continuously check how to use it you WILL MISS updates, new ways to structure it, new ways to use it, and even worse... alternatives to it!

So keep checking the documentation, keep searching for state management packages, you might have miss on others that are simpler, easier and just as good if not better.

The same goes for regular day to day JavaScript functions, like array functions, object functions, etc. Some become irrelevant, some become deprecated, and also you get new ones every now and then.

I agree with pretty much everything that's been said except the part about writing good code. Lack of concern about the quality of the code and its performance is why we have so many bad developers these days. Sure, if you're low on time, just make it work, but don't forget to refactor stuff later when possible. If you don't worry about the quality of your work you will never improve it. It's hard to reach where you aim for, but if you aim for perfection chances are you will become at least "very good". Aim for "enough" and you end up being mediocre. But again, it all depends on the time you have in your hands... after all we also need to deliver.

Thank you so much for this video!!
I'm sure I knew all of this already, but I really needed to hear it. As a 20+ years self taught developer, it really touched all my pain points.
Burnout is real, and it can do a lot of damage. It can affect the project you're working on and all your future projects.
Done is better than perfect should be tattooed on my wrists, so I had to look at it all day long. :)

As a side note, AI made it a lot easier to learn and search for stuff. I'm using Copilot inside VSCode, and I don't even have to leave the editor to search for something. There are no lies spoken here. I'm currently 15 years into my development journey and can confirm everything said is accurate.
Failure needs to be removed from our vocabulary as a four letter word. Failing is learning. Learning is failing. 
You are not a real developer unless you've brought down a production environment with your code at least once. Anyone willingly telling you they never have is doing so because they're either bragging (and everybody hates a bragger) or they're straight up lying to your face. Wrecking production at least once is an important right of passage for all developers. The key is to be open to learn as much as possible from that situation, every major mistake only needs to happen once (maybe sometimes twice) before you know what never to do again

I know I'll get some haters for this, but incidentally spending 3 hours to properly name a variable, especially as a junior developer,  and focused on a difficult situation, is NOT a waste of time.  It's thinking.  Just like writing is thinking.   It's the heart of proper documentation.   It forces you to understand what you are creating, and the relationship it has with other parts of your code.   When people say, "well-written code requires few comments",  90% of the time it's a result of proper naming.   Yes, 3 hours well exceeds the norms, but I think you learned a lot from that "failure"... I had a similar experience when I had to name a class.   With more experience and thinking, naming gets faster and better... and as a result, code maintenance will become easier.  If you were a veteran developer, taking 3 hours to focus on naming one thing, yes, I'd 100% agree with you.   Bottom line, don't sell yourself short... I hope everyone experiences a "naming crisis" at least once in their career, it makes you a much better developer

You are not ready, Start Anyway. Perfection is a lie. This helped me a lot.

Perfection is only achieved through teams. When you're alone if you demand perfection on yourself, you don't realize that 'perfection' is made by multiple team members looking over code and making corrections. The same works with an animation studio, you have supervisors and multiple people that will look over a single sketch until it's production ready.

I, personally, had that "aha, I am ready." moment or feeling. I was VERY intentional with where I spent my time in tutorials. I focused specifically on things that taught me how to use my software (game engine in this case), and even more specifically, how to apply those lessons into my own ideas so I can survive on my own. I actually started my first game with TOO much confidence... then realized how hard it was to scale tightly coupled systems that have rigid hierarchies and hard coded logic in actors that would have been better as components... It's funny how that moment of feeling ready was great at getting me motivated to start, but also something that has caused me 2 massive refactors...

Yes, yes, yes, and more yes! I have been saying this since I started game deving. You need to learn how to think in code before you write it. Your code has to have intent because the logic you write will need to perform a function, and that requires intent.

When you first start, it is 100% okay for you to have spaghetti code and hard code things (even though it is not correct and will not scale). That's how you learn why it doesn't work and can prepare to find solutions to avoid those mistakes. Keep learning how to avoid those pitfalls when designing your systems. Think ahead and ask questions. As you get more used to doing this, you will find how generalization and abstraction are huge helpers to avoid tight unintentional coupling. You will begin to realize that more generic code and smaller code actually makes debuging easier, and finding errors easier (finding errors can be harder than fixing them, but you need to have an idea of what to look for after you find the flaw). 

First, think about the code, plan the logic, walk through all the steps, their timing, and what dependencies are needed. Think about how the compiler will read the code. Then think about syntax. Once you have built what you planned, test it, test edge cases, test it forward and backward because end users will do random things, and you will want to account for that.

Accept you don't know all the answers. That is what QA is for. They will find the flaws you miss. So focus on making modular, scaleable, and generalized code that meets your basic needs, then build a bit more around that. Once you're happy with it, let people test your project. Then, fix what you were not aware of. Then, release it. Don't get stuck over engineering something that will never be released. A good engineer makes elegant code that can stand the test of time (if only they had said time to finish the project). The greatest engineer is one who ships their product.

Nobody remembers everything: In fact, I know several people I've worked with who remember almost everything they learn, at a very deep level. Even without ever having to put it into practice (like some things from university)! These guys made me think I was just bad at remembering. And they had achieved a very high level in a relatively short period of time.
I think after 13+ years in development, I can't even come close to the level of professional confidence they had after only a couple of years.

Many years later, I realized that I just have ADHD... and I remember things perfectly well even in detail if they are interesting.
But as soon as I solve a problem, the information needed to solve it is no longer important, and I forget it. So instead of a career ladder, I went on a career rollercoaster, up, down, up again. (If you have signs of ADHD, I recommend getting checked, methods of compensation can change your life dramatically)
ADHD in adults occurs in only 2-5% of the population, so I don't quite understand why neurotypical developers would have difficulty remembering something as simple as programming, where most of the problems have already been solved before us.

There are still a lot of perfectionists and people that think way too much of their own opinions out there.

here are key points:
You don't need to memorize everything in coding; knowing how to find answers is more important.

Shift from a passive 'consume mode' (watching tutorials) to an active 'create mode' (building projects).

Don't get stuck chasing perfection; 'done is better than perfect,' and shipping imperfect projects is crucial for learning.

You'll never feel completely ready to start a project or apply for a job, so you must start anyway.

The primary skill of a developer is problem-solving, not just writing syntax.

Focus on delivering value and creating functional products, as the elegance of the underlying code is secondary to the end-user.

Developer burnout is a serious risk; protect your energy by setting boundaries and taking breaks.

Embrace Googling and looking things up as a normal and essential part of the development process.

Here's what's funny about this: I'm a freelancer selling automation and AI-consulting services. I almost don't know anything about coding (yet). 

All services I have made by asking ChatGPT almost every step on how to do it. I just started doing it and when something didn't work I asked ChatGPT.

My customers don't know that. They only see that it works and that's what they care about. And of course I ain't gonna tell them.

I don't have imposter syndrom. It's quite the opposite. I laugh to myself that normies just don't get it. Because nowadays it's so easy to achieve almost everything you want if you get the knowledge.

And that is why I am learning coding too. I see the limits of my automation solutions and I have so many ideas which can only be achieved if I am able to code.

So I will learn everything about coding (simply because it's interesting, not because I need to) and will start coding ASAP. And if something doesn't work I can always ask my coach named ChatGPT.

Also, always ask yourself: If OpenAI can start selling their subscriptions fort ChatGPT a couple years ago even when it only worked like 50% of times correctly, why should you feel bad about selling stuff that isn't perfect? (Of course you should still TRY to be perfect or as good as possible. Don't be like OpenAI lol. It's about feeling bad that you aren't perfect, not about not trying to be.)

Hint on naming variables: Don't choose a name by what a variable contains. This might as well mean that all your variables are called "data". Try to incorporate the reason why a variable holds that data: "userInputNumber" is way better than "integer" because you remember where it came from as well as where it is going to end. My 2 cents as a programmer :)

No idea how your video landed in my feed. I never coded a line, and most likely never will. I am a product designer and everything you said applies for life in general. No matter what you want to learn or do in life, the rules are the same! As a young guy  I moved to Italy. It was my childhood dream! I started to talk to random people, I used all 5 words I knew over and over again. I went to language school, learned more words, talked more to people and learned more every day. I made a ton of mistakes, and nobody cared! Not me, not the beautiful Italian girl at the barâ€¦ I leaned by doing it, no matter what. Whenever I am stuck, or afraid of something I try to remember that time, that sense of freedom, that eagerness to learn I felt back then. I know nothing, but one thing: if I need it, I can learn it! This lesson in life was enough to have a successful career as a designer, outperform many people with way more talent or much stricter discipline!

But 20 years before you started 'coding', you actually would have known everything(or close to it) about a language. Before the Internet, you had no choice. There was no Googling basic syntax. I mean, hell, I've known companies to lock up language manuals(yes, printed ones on high quality paper and professionally produced) in cabinets like they were the crown jewels and not let anyone even touch them. That's how you knew you were a senior developer, when you didn't need the manuals 99% of the time. This led to problems, no doubt, as learning a language became a function of how good the seniors around you were, mitigated to a degree by college-level education. And yes, I've known idiots who only thought they knew everything but were in fact terrified of the language. Everybody laughed at them.

Of course, languages were simpler and didn't have a trillion libraries, but you could be what they today laughingly call Full Stack developers with a single language, one database, and whatever passed for shell scripting glue in your environment(JCL, MPE, MPEX, KORN, whatever they called scripting languages on VAX-VMS and DG Eclipse/Nova). Oh, and you probably needed to know how to control your dumb terminals for the UI(some environments abstracted this knowledge away).

This idea is that you don't need to know everything about a language is ludicrous, in my opinion. Sure, looking up libraries and how to use them is fine, I think, since nobody can possibly remember everything about so many. But basic language syntax? Nah, you'd better not be looking up Python list comprehensions if you claim to be a senior dev in that language, as an example.

One could claim that it's a different world now, and one would be correct, but that doesn't alter anything about software development.

You should care about your code. You should even consider using something like sonar qube.
The reason is maintainability. You should always us as much libraries, patterns and best practices your framework is recomending and following code standarts as much as possible.
If you start programming a lot of stuff yourself in plain code or start doing tons of workarounds, because you feel your std and framework libraries are limiting, you probably do something wrong.
It is important because you have to maintain your crappy code and you will forget what you did 2 weeks ago. Understanding old shty code or what other developers coded is causing huge headaches and is very annoying and frustrating. Especially if you have to update libraries and all your custom stuff falls apart. And you should also use as few third party libraries as possible and only use libraries, that are maintaned very well. Otherwise some crap gets abandoned and you have to implement something else from scratch. 
It is especially important because the eu created a law called digital service act which forces developers to keep their software secure. 
This is a huge thing and a big stone to overcome for beginners. 
I highly disagree, that nobody cares about your code. I strongly recommend to get a coder good enough to be able to review every commit and pair programming. 
If you dont follow it, a burnout is absolutely guaranteed and I can promise, that most people will just quit, because they cannot fix the bad code they wrote. It is the fastest way to lose a job. And also the main reason why people quit in the first place. And then you inherit some project from some coworker who quit, and you are the unlucky person who are forced to fix this crap. 
If you are a boss, this causes a chain reaction and all your coders will quit. Have fun finding new ones. Also have fun telling your customers, that you completely have to create the software again from scratch, because it is unfixable or impossible to update. This happend in our company already, it was a huge cost and you really dont want that. With the dsa you also might consider, that unhappy customers will sue you. Have fun winning on court, if you cannot document the stuff you coded. All your clever hooks are probably some fancy wannabe hacking that isnt even clever in the first place.
